metadata.title: Detecting Opinions in Tweets

sections.text: In view of the continuous growth of documents describing the opinions of various people circulating on the Internet, including Web 2.0, it is possible to express an opinion on each product on the net. In this essay, we examine the different opinions expressed in the tweets and classify them (positive, negative or neutral) using the emoticons for the Bayesian method and adjectives and adverbs for the Turney method. Keywords: opinion recognition, tweets, monitored approaches, semantic orientation, classification.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Today, we live in a world where information is available in abundance and of very different qualities; the Internet has evolved with new content; companies, for example, are storing more and more data; email is a very popular means of communication; documents that were once printed as manuscripts are now available in digital format; however, all this complex information would be meaningless if we could not easily access it; therefore, we need tools to search, sort, update, and analyze this available data; it is therefore necessary to provide systems to access the desired information as quickly as possible, thereby reducing human involvement; thousands of documents are readily available through networks and data processing supports, more than 90% of which are text-related documents; therefore, it will be difficult to access this information without the support of specific tools; text mining, which is a specialization of data mining, answers these problems; the study of text linguistics is based, in particular, on the tight linkages between forms and very specific forms.

sections.heading: STATE-OF-THE-ART
sections.text: The analysis of the text in terms of the study of feelings, opinions or viewpoints is not new [2], [15] but the field of opinion research and analysis of feelings has taken an important place since 2000 with the advent of the community web and the multiplication of forums on the net. Since then, "Opinion Mining" has become an important concern for any company that wishes to better understand the preferences and dislikes of its customers, relying on the opinions of those who want to compare the products before they buy them. Thus, Morinaga et al. [11] explain how they verify the reputation of the target products by analyzing the criticism of the customers. First, they access the websites that discuss the product in question and extract the sentences that express the opinion. Subsequently, they classify the sentences according to whether they express a negative opinion or a positive opinion and derive the popularity of the product from it. sections.heading: CREATION OF THE LEXICONS OF OPINION
sections.text: This method requires the creation of one or more opinion dictionaries. Three methods can be used to create such dictionaries:

sections.heading: Manual Method
sections.text: Regardless of the method of constructing the lexicon, a first stage of manual classification is necessary. Corpora-based method It completes the lexicon of opinions and consists of the use of coordinating conjunctions that exist between an already classified word and an unclassified word [4], [5], [8]. For example, if a conjunction AND a positively classified word in the lexicon of opinions separates from an unclassified word, then the unclassified word is considered positive. On the contrary, if the conjunction BUT separates a positive classified word and an unclassified word, then the unclassified word is considered negative. The conjunctions that are used are as follows: AND, OR, BUT, EHER, NEHER and an unclassified word determined on the basis of SITOS [SITO].

sections.heading: APPROACHES BASED ON MACHINE LEARNING
sections.text: In these approaches, words are usually regarded as equivalent variables, so that the semantic aspect is not taken into account. Monitored classification methods are most commonly used to classify opinions. These methods consist of building a classification model based on samples. Samples are data whose class we already know. In this case, we refer to classified or labeled data.

sections.heading: HYBRID APPROACHES
sections.text: Different types of hybridization methods are discussed in the literature, using all the elements described in the two previous approaches. To these approaches, we can distinguish three different methods, namely: Linguistics in the Service of Machine Learning; Machine Learning in the Service of Linguistics; A fusion a posteriori of the results of the two approaches.

sections.heading: PROPOSED APPROACH
sections.text: In our approach, we used two techniques, namely supervised training, which is represented by the Bayesian probabilistic model, and the SO, which is represented by the Turney algorithm.

sections.heading: CONSTITUTION OF CORPUS
sections.text: Despite the research we have done, we could not find a corpus of tweets (all corpus on the net are not free) and, as a result, we have collected various tweets that come from a corpus. To do this, we followed the following steps: Selection of tweets For the collection of tweets, we have a Java API (Application Programming Interface) called "Twitter4J 'Twitter4J allows access to the Twitter database to recover / post information. The API is divided into four classes: SEARCH: allows to ask Twitter to restore simple data, primarily tweets. REST: advanced extension of SEARCH, which provides access to advanced functionalities of Twitter, such as users, followers to see the status, publish information on its account, etc. STREAMING: allows communication with Twitter in streaming mode. The advanced function of the API is that it allows access to large amounts of Twitter data and access to those websites are limited by the functions of the websites.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION AND PERSPECTIVES
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented two approaches to recognizing opinions in Twitter tweets - a supervised learning approach and a SO approach; the first is based on emoticons, while the second is based on adjectives. Experiments conducted have yielded positive results, and many perspectives have yet to be explored in this rapidly expanding field.
